bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, November 13, 1947

div1.p: Hench writes that despite the Rockefeller Foundation's refusal of financial support for the Camp Lazear project, he would like to meet with Packard to seek advice from him.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, November 13, 1947
div1.opener:
November 13, 1947
Mr. Arthur W. Packard
Room 5600 30
Rockefeller Plaza
New York City, New York
My dear Mr. Packard:
div1.p:
I sincerely appreciate your telegram. I am coming to New
York anyhow to a meeting of the American Committee of the International
League against Rheumatism of which I am Chairman. I will be at the
Hotel Waldorf from the 18th to the 20th but have a meeting of our
Committee on the 19th. I would appreciate it greatly if you would
let me call on you if possible, on the 18th, and I will get in touch
with your secretary shortly after my arrival. I believe I understand
your position and will certainly not press matters. However, I do need
some advice which I believe you can give me.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
